title: Getting Started
text: First, load {salesforcer} package log . two ways authenticate: OAuth 2.0 Basic Username-Password NOTE: Beginning February 1st, 2022, Salesforce requiring customers enable multi-factor authentication, means basic authentication using password security token longer work. function sf_auth() return error message: Also, best practice use OAuth 2.0 passwords embedded within scripts. OAuth 2.0 credentials stored locally cached file titled .httr-oauth-salesforcer current working directory. package automatically refresh cached token expires call sf_auth() every R session .httr-oauth-salesforcer file present working directory. Setting Connected App OAuth Just note, ’s necessary setup Connected App Salesforce use OAuth 2.0 authentication. difference authentication run client created associated {salesforcer} package. using package client, giving access Salesforce anyone, package just medium connect data. wanted control specify options like : Using proxy connection required connect Salesforce via proxy able specify parameters options, well. call via httr proxy settings passed along Salesforce authentication. logging sf_auth(), can check connectivity looking information returned current user. information !
code: INVALID_LOGIN: Invalid username, password, security token; or user locked out. library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(salesforcer) sf_auth() options(salesforcer.consumer_key = "012345678901-99thisisatest99connected33app22key") options(salesforcer.consumer_secret = "Th1s1sMyConsumerS3cr3t")  sf_auth() options(salesforcer.proxy_url = "64.251.21.73") # IP or a named domain options(salesforcer.proxy_port = 8080) options(salesforcer.proxy_username = "user") options(salesforcer.proxy_password = "pass") options(salesforcer.proxy_auth = "ntlm")  sf_auth() # pull down information of person logged in # it's a simple easy call to get started  # and confirm a connection to the APIs user_info <- sf_user_info() sprintf("Organization Id: %s", user_info$organizationId) #> [1] "Organization Id: 00D6A0000003dN3UAI" sprintf("User Id: %s", user_info$userId) #> [1] "User Id: 0056A000000MPRjQAO"

title: Getting Started
text: Salesforce objects objects contain records. One default object “Contact” object. example shows create two records Contact object.
code: n <- 2 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n)) created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts, "Contact") created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 003Kg000002AbQNIA0 TRUE    #> 2 003Kg000002AbQOIA0 TRUE

title: Getting Started
text: Retrieve pulls specific set records fields. ’s similar running query, doesn’t use SOQL. example retrieve data just created.
code: retrieved_records <- sf_retrieve(ids=created_records$id,                                   fields=c("FirstName", "LastName"),                                   object_name="Contact") retrieved_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   sObject Id                 FirstName LastName         #>   <chr>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 Contact 003Kg000002AbQNIA0 Test      Contact-Create-1 #> 2 Contact 003Kg000002AbQOIA0 Test      Contact-Create-2

title: Getting Started
text: Salesforce proprietary form SQL called SOQL (Salesforce Object Query Language). SOQL powerful tool allows return fields records almost object Salesforce including Accounts, Contacts, Tasks, Opportunities, even Attachments! example grab data just created including Account object information Contact record associated . NOTE: example , ’ll notice "Account.Name" column appear results. SOAP REST APIs return empty Account object record relationship account ( see #78). reliable way extract rebuild empty columns based query string. Account information, additional column titled "Account.Name" appear results. Note, Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0 APIs return "Account.Name" column NA values query return results differently.
code: my_soql <- sprintf("SELECT Id,                             Account.Name,                             FirstName,                             LastName                      FROM Contact                      WHERE Id in ('%s')",                     paste0(created_records$id , collapse="','"))  queried_records <- sf_query(my_soql) queried_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName LastName         #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 003Kg000002AbQNIA0 Test      Contact-Create-1 #> 2 003Kg000002AbQOIA0 Test      Contact-Create-2

title: Getting Started
text: creating records can update using sf_update(). Updating record requires pass Salesforce Id record. Salesforce creates unique 18-character identifier record uses know record attach update information provide. Simply include field column update dataset called “Id” information matched. example update records created earlier new first name called “TestTest”.
code: # Update some of those records queried_records <- queried_records %>%   mutate(FirstName = "TestTest")  updated_records <- sf_update(queried_records, object_name="Contact") updated_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 003Kg000002AbQNIA0 TRUE    #> 2 003Kg000002AbQOIA0 TRUE

title: Getting Started
text: can also delete records Salesforce. method implements “soft” delete meaning deleted records go Recycle Bin can emptied queried later event record needed.
code: deleted_records <- sf_delete(updated_records$id) deleted_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   id                 success errors     #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 003Kg000002AbQNIA0 TRUE    <list [0]> #> 2 003Kg000002AbQOIA0 TRUE    <list [0]>

title: Getting Started
text: Finally, Salesforce unique method called “upsert” allows create /update records time. specifically, record found based “External Id” field, Salesforce create record instead updating one. example create 2 records, upsert 3, 2 matched updated one created. NOTE: need create custom field target object ensure labeled “External Id” field.
code: n <- 2 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n),                         My_External_Id__c=letters[1:n]) created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts, "Contact")  upserted_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                             LastName = paste0("Contact-Upsert-", 1:n),                              My_External_Id__c=letters[1:n]) new_record <- tibble(FirstName = "Test",                      LastName = paste0("Contact-Upsert-", n+1),                       My_External_Id__c=letters[n+1]) upserted_contacts <- bind_rows(upserted_contacts, new_record)  upserted_records <- sf_upsert(input_data=upserted_contacts,                                object_name="Contact",                                external_id_fieldname="My_External_Id__c") upserted_records #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   id                 success created #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   #> 1 003Kg000002AbQSIA0 TRUE    FALSE   #> 2 003Kg000002AbQTIA0 TRUE    FALSE   #> 3 003Kg000002AbQXIA0 TRUE    TRUE

First, authenticate load required packages analysis. example , demonstrate create record, use control arguments prevent creation showing Chatter feeds setting DisableFeedTrackingHeader. notice argument DisableFeedTrackingHeader can included right function without documentation existing sf_create function. dots (...) allow pass dozen different control parameters documentation tedious create maintain multiple functions package. However, notice documentation entry control argument link function called sf_control can use directly pass control simply review documentation possible control parameters defaults. can review various control options detail trying set . may also noticed argument DisableFeedTrackingHeader formatted list element inside called disableFeedTracking set TRUE. may seem redundant two reasons . First, exactly Salesforce APIs documents options, typically referred “headers” passed named header HTTP request header fields values provided header. Second, headers multiple fields values list way provide multiple named fields values single header entity.
code: library(salesforcer) sf_auth() new_contact <- c(FirstName = "Jenny",                   LastName = "Williams",                   Email = "jennyw@gmail.com") record1 <- sf_create(new_contact,                      object_name = "Contact",                      DisableFeedTrackingHeader = list(disableFeedTracking = TRUE)) record1 #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   success errors     #>   <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 FALSE   <list [1]>

title: Passing Control Args
text: DuplicateRuleHeader controls whether duplicate rules followed inserting records API, three fields: allowSave - duplicate rule, Alert option enabled, bypass alerts save duplicate records setting property true. Prevent duplicate records saved setting property false. includeRecordDetails - Get fields values records detected duplicates setting property true. Get record IDs records detected duplicates setting property false. runAsCurrentUser - Make sure sharing rules current user enforced duplicate rules run setting property true. Use sharing rules specified class request setting property false. sharing rules specified, Apex code runs system context sharing rules current user enforced. Specifying arguments requires list structure R, may seem redundant cases, necessary follow order build API request correctly. Per description , note setting allowSave=TRUE override rules “Action Create” rule set “Block”. duplicate rule’s action “Allow” alert, setting allowSave=TRUE means record created warning message. allowSave=FALSE, record prevented created. additional information DuplicateRuleHeader, please see Salesforce documentation : https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api.meta/api/sforce_api_header_duplicateruleheader.htm Finally, may notice use certain control arguments permitted based API. example, DuplicateRuleHeader implemented REST API like SOAP API. example take note two things: using REST API setting DuplicateRuleHeader, notice warning header ignored. receive warnings trying set control parameters API operation recognize particular control. example, bypass duplicate rule alert create record using REST API like can SOAP API.
code: # override the duplicate rules ... record2 <- sf_create(new_contact,                      object_name = "Contact",                      DuplicateRuleHeader = list(allowSave = TRUE,                                                  includeRecordDetails = FALSE,                                                  runAsCurrentUser = TRUE)) record2 #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 003Kg000002AbQcIAK TRUE  # ... or succumb to the duplicate rules record3 <- sf_create(new_contact,                      object_name = "Contact",                      DuplicateRuleHeader = list(allowSave = FALSE,                                                  includeRecordDetails = FALSE,                                                  runAsCurrentUser = TRUE)) record3 #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   success errors     #>   <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 FALSE   <list [1]> record4 <- sf_create(new_contact,                      object_name = "Contact",                      DuplicateRuleHeader = list(allowSave = FALSE,                                                  includeRecordDetails = FALSE,                                                  runAsCurrentUser = TRUE),                      api_type = "REST") #> Warning: Ignoring the following controls which are not used in the REST API: #> DuplicateRuleHeader record4 #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   success errors     #>   <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 FALSE   <list [1]>

what: REST vs. SOAP API query performance test
title: Supported Queries
text: small example roughly demonstrate magnitude performance difference REST SOAP APIs querying 1,000 records. Setup performance test Performance test  seen limited test , REST API can anywhere 4-6x faster SOAP API query 1,000 contact records associated single Account. Breaking number records returned smaller batches setting QueryOptions = list(batchSize = 200) typically affect result much also depends number fields query. REST API default 2,000 records per batch minimum 200 maximum 2,000. SOAP API default 500 records per batch. APIs important note guarantee requested batch size actual batch size. Changes made necessary maximize performance. example, SOAP API states “batch size 200 SOQL statement selects two custom fields type long text”. REST API mentions limit imposed Salesforce’s app servers around 20,000 characters can cause batches smaller. short, ’s generally okay use default batch sizes since Salesforce may optimize specified batch size anyways.
code: # create a new account  # (if replicating, you may or may not have an external id field in your Org) prefix <- paste0("APerfTest-", as.integer(runif(1,1,99999))) new_account <- sf_create(   tibble(     Name = "Test Account For Performance Test",      My_External_Id__c = prefix,     Description = paste0("This is a test account with 1,000 records for ",                           "testing the performance differences between the ",                           "SOAP and REST APIs.")   ),    object_name = "Account" )  # create and associate a thousand new contacts with that account # (again, you may or may not have an external id field in your Org) n <- 1000 prefix <- paste0("CPerfTest-", as.integer(runif(1,1,99999)), "-") new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Query-Vignette", 1:n),                         test_number__c = 999.9,                        AccountId = rep(new_account$id, n),                        My_External_Id__c=paste0(prefix, 1:n)) new_contacts_res <- sf_create(new_contacts, "Contact", api_type = "Bulk 2.0") qry <- function(api_type){   sf_query(     sprintf("SELECT Id, Name, Owner.Id,                 (SELECT Id, LastName, Owner.Id FROM Contacts)              FROM Account             WHERE Id = '%s'",              new_account$id),      api_type = api_type   ) } res <- microbenchmark::microbenchmark(   qry("REST"),   qry("SOAP"),   times = 5,    unit = "s" ) #> Warning in microbenchmark::microbenchmark(qry("REST"), qry("SOAP"), times = 5, #> : less accurate nanosecond times to avoid potential integer overflows res #> Unit: seconds #>         expr       min        lq      mean    median        uq       max neval #>  qry("REST") 0.1716782 0.1724434 0.2088557 0.1804810 0.2009475 0.3187283     5 #>  qry("SOAP") 0.4973334 0.5061490 0.5098101 0.5107634 0.5141724 0.5206325     5  suppressWarnings(suppressMessages(   ggplot2::autoplot(res) +      ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(name="Time [seconds]", n.breaks=6) ))

what: When to use the Bulk APIs for queries
title: Supported Queries
text: general rule thumb using Bulk APIs (Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0) queries anytime need retrieve 10,000 records. main reasons use Bulk APIs twofold. First, support complex relationship queries aggregate queries. need write nested relationship aggregate query involving large number records may tempted use REST API. However, recommended perform two separate bulk queries retrieve records need join aggregate results R. two queries trying pull contacts account get count many contacts per account. lot records, using REST API return results may feasible. Even though Bulk APIs handle query, can pull massive amounts data quickly. case can pull Contact records Account records perform calculation using dplyr, like : second reason use Bulk APIs performance overhead associated every bulk (asynchronous) job involves checking status job succeeds fails retrieving results. example provided can take code example run performance test queries return 10K, 100K, 1M+ records see Bulk APIs outperform REST API. Note Bulk 1.0 API requires users specify target object along submitted SOQL. needed creating bulk job manage execute query. can see {salesforcer} package try infer object query explicitly provided. guess correctly, please specify. Cleanup performance tests keeping track account ids used tests, fairly easy find delete test records Org save space.
code: # nested relationship query  # (supposed to return the id and first name of all contacts on each account) try(   sf_query(     "SELECT Id, Name,        (SELECT Id, FirstName FROM Contacts)     FROM Account",     api_type = "Bulk 2.0"   ) ) #> Request failed [400]. Retrying in 1 seconds... #> Request failed [400]. Retrying in 1 seconds... #> Error : API_ERROR: Aggregate Relationships not supported in Bulk V2 Query with CSV content type  # aggregate query # (supposed to return the count of contacts per account) try(   sf_query(     "SELECT Account.Id, Count(Name) contacts_n     FROM Contact     GROUP BY Account.Id",       api_type = "Bulk 2.0"   ) ) #> Request failed [400]. Retrying in 1 seconds... #> Request failed [400]. Retrying in 3.9 seconds... #> Error : API_ERROR: Aggregate Relationships not supported in Bulk Query contacts <- sf_query("SELECT Id, FirstName, Account.Id                      FROM Contact",                       api_type = "Bulk 2.0")  accounts <- sf_query("SELECT Id, Name                       FROM Account",                       api_type = "Bulk 2.0")  nested_query_recs <- accounts %>%    left_join(contacts %>%                rename(`Contact.Id` = Id,                       `Contact.FirstName` = FirstName),              by = c("Id" = "Account.Id")) nested_query_recs #> # A tibble: 518 × 4 #>   Id                 Name                           Contact.Id Contact.FirstName #>   <chr>              <chr>                          <chr>      <chr>             #> 1 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … 0033s0000… KEEP              #> 2 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … 0033s0000… KEEP              #> 3 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … 0033s0000… KEEP              #> 4 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … 0033s0000… KEEP              #> 5 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … 0033s0000… KEEP              #> # ℹ 513 more rows  aggregate_query_recs <- nested_query_recs %>%    group_by(Id) %>%   summarize(.groups = 'drop',              contacts_n = sum(!is.na(Contact.Id))) aggregate_query_recs #> # A tibble: 17 × 2 #>   Id                 contacts_n #>   <chr>                   <int> #> 1 0013s00000zFdugAAC        300 #> 2 0013s00000zFgA6AAK          0 #> 3 0013s000014jF2HAAU          0 #> 4 0013s000014jF2vAAE          0 #> 5 0013s000014jFj6AAE          0 #> # ℹ 12 more rows qry_compare <- function(api_type){   soql <- sprintf("SELECT Id, LastName, Account.Id, Account.Name, Owner.Id                    FROM Contact                    WHERE Account.Id = '%s'",                     new_account$id)   sf_query(soql, api_type = api_type) }  res <- microbenchmark::microbenchmark(   qry_compare("REST"),   qry_compare("Bulk 1.0"),   qry_compare("Bulk 2.0"),   times = 5,    unit = "s" ) queried_records <- sf_query(soql, api_type = "Bulk 1.0") #> Guessed 'Contact' as the object_name from supplied SOQL. #> Please set `object_name` explicitly if this is incorrect because it is required by the Bulk APIs. # cleanup performance test Contact records ... contacts_to_delete <- sf_query(   sprintf("SELECT Id            FROM Contact            WHERE Account.Id = '%s'",           new_account$id) ) sf_delete(contacts_to_delete$Id, "Contact", api_type="Bulk 2.0") #> # A tibble: 99 × 4 #>   Id                 sf__Id             sf__Created sf__Error #>   <chr>              <chr>              <lgl>       <lgl>     #> 1 003Kg000002AbQhIAK 003Kg000002AbQhIAK FALSE       NA        #> 2 003Kg000002AbQiIAK 003Kg000002AbQiIAK FALSE       NA        #> 3 003Kg000002AbQjIAK 003Kg000002AbQjIAK FALSE       NA        #> 4 003Kg000002AbQkIAK 003Kg000002AbQkIAK FALSE       NA        #> 5 003Kg000002AbQlIAK 003Kg000002AbQlIAK FALSE       NA        #> # ℹ 94 more rows  # ... and finally delete the account sf_delete(new_account$id) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   id                 success errors     #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 001Kg0000034ppqIAA TRUE    <list [0]>

title: Supported Queries
text: first type relationship query common child parent. example, Contact object (child) parent, Account object. order pull parent object fields child record query, just need prefix fields related object concatenating name object field name separated period. example retrieving Contact object records relationship Account. Note, Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0 APIs return "Account.Name" column NA values query return results differently. Finally, one aspect note Bulk 2.0 API support child--parent-grandparent relationships seen example :
code: # child-to-parent relationship (e.g. Account.Name from Contact record) sf_query(   "SELECT Id, FirstName, Account.Name   FROM Contact   WHERE Account.Id != null" ) #> # A tibble: 414 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName Account.Name                         #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>                                #> 1 0033s000012NkzwAAC KEEP      KEEP Test Account With Child Records #> 2 0033s000012NkzxAAC KEEP      KEEP Test Account With Child Records #> 3 0033s000012NkzyAAC KEEP      KEEP Test Account With Child Records #> 4 0033s000012NkzzAAC KEEP      KEEP Test Account With Child Records #> 5 0033s000012Nl00AAC KEEP      KEEP Test Account With Child Records #> # ℹ 409 more rows # child-to-parent relationship (e.g. Account.Name from Contact record) sf_query(   "SELECT Id, FirstName, Account.Name   FROM Contact   WHERE Account.Id = null" ) #> # A tibble: 464 × 2 #>   Id                 FirstName #>   <chr>              <chr>     #> 1 003Kg000002AaGiIAK Test      #> 2 003Kg000002AaGjIAK Test      #> 3 003Kg000002AaJ7IAK Test      #> 4 003Kg000002AaJ8IAK Test      #> 5 003Kg000002AaGYIA0 Test      #> # ℹ 459 more rows try(   sf_query("SELECT Id, FirstName, Account.Owner.Id             FROM Contact",             api_type = "Bulk 2.0") ) #> # A tibble: 878 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName Account.Owner.Id #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 0033s000012Nd60AAC Jenny     NA               #> 2 0033s000012Nd65AAC Jenny     NA               #> 3 0033s000012Nd6FAAS Jenny     NA               #> 4 0033s000012Nd6UAAS Jenny     NA               #> 5 0033s000012NdARAA0 Jenny     NA               #> # ℹ 873 more rows

title: Supported Queries
text: Instead “looking ” related field, users can write queries retrieve individual records related parent. example, like Accounts Contacts can write query like : first glance query may appear lookup query Contact object includes account id name. However, small difference every Account included, regardless whether Contact. can helpful want ensure query contains parent records child records, exist. Also, note plural object name used inside nested query (“Contacts” instead “Contact”). Finally, parent--child nested query can also contain child--parent lookup relationship within . example Owner Id Contact included can know responsible Contacts Account.
code: sf_query(   "SELECT Id, Name,      (SELECT Id, FirstName FROM Contacts)   FROM Account" ) #> # A tibble: 419 × 4 #>   Id                 Name                           Contact.FirstName Contact.Id #>   <chr>              <chr>                          <chr>             <chr>      #> 1 0013s00000zFgA6AAK KEEP Test Account With Child … NA                NA         #> 2 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … KEEP              0033s0000… #> 3 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … KEEP              0033s0000… #> 4 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … KEEP              0033s0000… #> 5 0013s00000zFdugAAC KEEP Test Account With Child … KEEP              0033s0000… #> # ℹ 414 more rows sf_query(   "SELECT Name, Owner.Id,      (SELECT Id, FirstName, Owner.Id FROM Contacts)    FROM Account" ) #> # A tibble: 419 × 5 #>   Name                    Contact.FirstName Contact.Id Contact.Owner.Id Owner.Id #>   <chr>                   <chr>             <chr>      <chr>            <chr>    #> 1 KEEP Test Account With… NA                NA         NA               0056A00… #> 2 KEEP Test Account With… KEEP              0033s0000… 0056A000000MPRj… 0056A00… #> 3 KEEP Test Account With… KEEP              0033s0000… 0056A000000MPRj… 0056A00… #> 4 KEEP Test Account With… KEEP              0033s0000… 0056A000000MPRj… 0056A00… #> 5 KEEP Test Account With… KEEP              0033s0000… 0056A000000MPRj… 0056A00… #> # ℹ 414 more rows

title: Supported Queries
text: issue query please submit {salesforcer} GitHub repository : https://github.com/StevenMMortimer/salesforcer/issues. maintainer, queries tough debug every Salesforce Org unique. Custom objects relationships created Salesforce Org may different even impossible test another Org. filing issue please make attempt understand query debug little bit . suggestions: Slightly modify function call sf_query() observe results. prompting questions may assist : see set verbose=TRUE argument? happens change control argument, specifically batch size? happens try using different API (e.g. “SOAP” vs “REST” “Bulk 1.0” vs “Bulk 2.0”)? happens change query slightly? need parent--child nested relationship query child--parent lookup suffice? Check Salesforce’s Workbench tool see constructs specific queries debugging. tool available https://workbench.developerforce.com requires Salesforce login (credentials normally use). Double check Salesforce’s SOQL reference guide see whether query supported limited way. Review query unit tests : https://github.com/StevenMMortimer/salesforcer/blob/main/tests/testthat/test-query.R. unit tests written cover variety use cases track changes made newly released versions Salesforce API (typically 4 year). tests excellent source examples may helpful troubleshooting query. Roll sleeves dive source code {salesforcer} package. main scripts review : https://github.com/StevenMMortimer/salesforcer/blob/main/R/query.R https://github.com/StevenMMortimer/salesforcer/blob/main/R/utils-query.R

title: Transitioning from RForcecom
text: June 9, 2021, {RForcecom} package removed CRAN. can still use installing archive, strongly recommend using {salesforcer} instead. existing functionality {RForcecom} optimized within {salesforcer} new functionality added .

what: Salesforce Requires MFA Which Prevents RForcecom Basic Auth Log in
title: Transitioning from RForcecom
text: Basic authentication (password security token) longer work since Salesforce announced customers migrated MFA beginning February 1st, 2022 (link). result, basic authentication routine used {RForcecom} legacy, compatibility method written {salesforcer} longer work. Please migrate {salesforcer} use sf_auth() generate OAuth 2.0 token. examples longer work.

title: Transitioning from RForcecom
text: {salesforcer} supports OAuth 2.0 authentication preferred, backward compatibility provides username-password authentication routine implemented {RForcecom}. example running function packages side--side producing result. First, authenticate load required packages analysis. Note must set API version calls session create new sessionId stuck version 35.0 (default RForcecom::rforcecom.login()). functions {salesforcer} implement API calls available version 35.0.
code: library(salesforcer) sf_auth() # Beginning February 1, 2022, basic authentication will no longer work. You must # log in to Salesforce using MFA (generating an OAuth 2.0 token typically from  # the browser).  # the RForcecom way # RForcecom::rforcecom.login(username, paste0(password, security_token),  #                            apiVersion=getOption("salesforcer.api_version")) # replicated in salesforcer package session <- salesforcer::rforcecom.login(username,                                           paste0(password, security_token),                                           apiVersion = getOption("salesforcer.api_version")) session['sessionID'] <- "{MASKED}" session

title: Transitioning from RForcecom
text: “CRUD” operations (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) {RForcecom} package operate one record time. One benefit using {salesforcer} package operations accept named vector (one record) entire data.frame tbl_df records churn . However, rest assured replicated functions behave exactly way hesitant making switch. example showing reduction code using {salesforcer} like create multiple records.
code: n <- 2 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n))  # the RForcecom way (requires a loop) # rforcecom_results <- NULL # for(i in 1:nrow(new_contacts)){ #   temp <- RForcecom::rforcecom.create(session,  #                                       objectName = "Contact",  #                                       fields = unlist(slice(new_contacts,i))) #   rforcecom_results <- bind_rows(rforcecom_results, temp) # }  # the better way in salesforcer to do multiple records salesforcer_results <- sf_create(new_contacts, object_name="Contact") salesforcer_results #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 003Kg000002AbSNIA0 TRUE    #> 2 003Kg000002AbSOIA0 TRUE

Attachment data, example, attachment’s Id, ParentId, Name, Body, ModifiedDate, attributes stored Attachment object, Standard Object Salesforce.
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(salesforcer) sf_auth()

title: Working with Attachments
text: cover 2 different methods creating attachments: Uploading local files Attachments one time using SOAP REST API (common usage) Uploading large batches files using Bulk API, zips files upload Uploading local files Attachments (SOAP REST) uploading attachment stored locally (.e. computer), can provide absolute relative path current working directory. Name column omitted, name attachment appears Salesforce base file name extension. example, path provided “/Documents/attachments/doc1.pdf”, Name field set “doc1.pdf”. example , upload three attachments two different parent records. Note: Make sure replace paths ParentIds example file paths exist local machine Ids records Salesforce org.
code: # define the ParentIds where the attachments will be shown in Salesforce parent_record_id1 <- "0016A0000035mJ4" parent_record_id2 <- "0016A0000035mJ5"  # provide the file paths of where the attachments exist locally on your machine # in this case we are referencing images included within the salesforcer package,  # but any absolute or relative path locally will work file_path1 <- system.file("extdata", "cloud.png", package="salesforcer") file_path2 <- system.file("extdata", "logo.png", package="salesforcer") file_path3 <- system.file("extdata", "old-logo.png", package="salesforcer")  # create a data.frame or tbl_df out of this information attachment_details <- tibble(Body = rep(c(file_path1,                                            file_path2,                                            file_path3),                                          times=2),                              ParentId = rep(c(parent_record_id1,                                                parent_record_id2),                                              each=3))  # create the attachments! result <- sf_create_attachment(attachment_details) result #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 00PKg000001EiCWMA0 TRUE    #> 2 00PKg000001EiCbMAK TRUE    #> 3 00PKg000001EiCgMAK TRUE    #> 4 00PKg000001EiClMAK TRUE    #> 5 00PKg000001Ei3fMAC TRUE    #> # ℹ 1 more row

title: Working with Attachments
text: uploading attachments Salesforce can download first querying metadata Attachment object. metadata provides Id blob data attachment download. convenience function, sf_download_attachment(), created download attachments quickly. example shows query metadata attachments belonging particular ParentId. downloading attachments using Body important consider whether attachment names repeated duplicates. , attachments exact name overwritten local filesystem downloaded. avoid problem two common strategies: Create new column (e.g. unique_name) concatenation Attachment Id Attachment’s name guaranteed unique. Save attachments separate folders ParentId record. long ParentId record doesn’t name attachments name, Strategy #2 work. addition, may help better organize documents planning download many upload Salesforce using Bulk API demonstrated later script.
code: # pull down all attachments associated with a particular record queried_attachments <- sf_query(sprintf("SELECT Id, Body, Name, ParentId                                          FROM Attachment                                          WHERE ParentId IN ('%s', '%s')",                                           parent_record_id1, parent_record_id2)) queried_attachments #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>   Id                 Body                                         Name  ParentId #>   <chr>              <chr>                                        <chr> <chr>    #> 1 00PKg000001EiCbMAK /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00… logo… 0016A00… #> 2 00PKg000001EiCWMA0 /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00… clou… 0016A00… #> 3 00PKg000001EgtEMAS /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00… old-… 0016A00… #> 4 00PKg000001EiCgMAK /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00… old-… 0016A00… #> 5 00PKg000001EiCqMAK /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00… old-… 0016A00… #> # ℹ 5 more rows # create a new folder for each ParentId in the dataset temp_dir <- tempdir() for (pid in unique(queried_attachments$ParentId)){   dir.create(file.path(temp_dir, pid), showWarnings = FALSE) # ignore if already exists }  # create a new columns in the queried data so that we can pass this information  # on to the function `sf_download_attachment()` that will actually perform the download queried_attachments <- queried_attachments %>%    # Strategy 1: Unique file names (ununsed here, but shown as an example)   mutate(unique_name = paste(Id, Name, sep='___')) %>%    # Strategy 2: Separate folders per parent   mutate(Path = file.path(temp_dir, ParentId))  # download all of the attachments for a single ParentId record to their own folder download_result <- mapply(sf_download_attachment,                            body = queried_attachments$Body,                            name = queried_attachments$Name,                            path = queried_attachments$Path) download_result #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EiCbMAK/Body  #>     "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ4QAI/logo.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EiCWMA0/Body  #>    "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ4QAI/cloud.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EgtEMAS/Body  #> "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ4QAI/old-logo.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EiCgMAK/Body  #> "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ4QAI/old-logo.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EiCqMAK/Body  #> "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ5QAI/old-logo.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EiClMAK/Body  #>    "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ5QAI/cloud.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001Ei3fMAC/Body  #>     "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ5QAI/logo.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EgtFMAS/Body  #>    "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ5QAI/cloud.png"  #>                               /services/data/v61.0/sobjects/Attachment/00PKg000001EgtGMAS/Body  #>     "/var/folders/g6/rgtlsw6n123b0gt5483s5_cm0000gn/T//RtmpOywQ2o/0016A0000035mJ5QAI/logo.png"  #> title: Working with Attachments
text: Attachment record created, still able update content metadata (Name, IsPrivate, OwnerId) record. sf_update_attachment() function works just like sf_update() except need include Body column content attachment help. NOTE: just want update metadata Attachment content , can simply use sf_update() modify fields Body field record. example demonstrates add attachment record, download , zip , re-upload record order save disk space Org. function sf_delete_attachment(), simply wraps sf_delete() feel free use clarity code ’re working attachments use sf_delete(). Uploading large batches attachments using Bulk API SOAP REST APIs good working attachments time. However, Bulk API can invoked using api_type=“Bulk 1.0” automatically take data.frame tbl_df Attachment field data create ZIP file CSV manifest required API upload. example , downloaded three attachments belonging two different parent records. Assuming run code files computer can demonstrate can uploaded using Bulk 1.0 API. NOTE: v48.0 (Spring ’20), appear Bulk 2.0 API supports working Attachments, Bulk 1.0 API must used bulk functionality. Finally, able update Attachments Bulk API just shown REST/SOAP API examples.
code: # upload a PDF to a particular record as an Attachment file_path <- system.file("extdata",                          "data-wrangling-cheatsheet.pdf",                          package = "salesforcer") parent_record_id <- "0036A000002C6MmQAK" # replace with your own ParentId! attachment_details <- tibble(Body = file_path, ParentId = parent_record_id) create_result <- sf_create_attachment(attachment_details)  # download, zip, and re-upload the PDF pdf_path <- sf_download_attachment(sf_id = create_result$id[1]) zipped_path <- paste0(pdf_path, ".zip") zip(zipped_path, pdf_path, flags = "-qq") # quiet zipping messages attachment_details <- tibble(Id = create_result$id, Body = zipped_path) sf_update_attachment(attachment_details) #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 00PKg000001EiCvMAK TRUE sf_delete_attachment(ids = create_result$id) #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 00PKg000001EiCvMAK TRUE # sf_delete(ids = create_result$id) # would also work # create the attachment metadata required (Name, Body, ParentId) attachment_details <- queried_attachments %>%    mutate(Body = file.path(Path, Name)) %>%    select(Name, Body, ParentId) result <- sf_create_attachment(attachment_details, api_type="Bulk 1.0") result #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>   Id                 Success Created Error #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl> #> 1 00PKg000001EiD0MAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 2 00PKg000001EiD1MAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 3 00PKg000001EiD2MAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 4 00PKg000001EiD3MAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 5 00PKg000001EiD4MAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> # ℹ 5 more rows

what: Extending to Documents and Other Blob Data
title: Working with Attachments
text: commands working Attachments also work uploading documents blob data well. Documents just like Attachments Salesforce except instead associated ParentId associated FolderId blob associated upon creation. brief example uploading PDF (“Document”) Folder Documents, users also able save storage specifying Url instead file path Body content stored locally. Specifying Url field reference URL instead uploading Salesforce org, thereby saving space limited organization.
code: # the function supports inserting all types of blob content, just update the  # object_name argument to add the PDF as a Document instead of an Attachment document_details <- tibble(Name = "Data Wrangling Cheatsheet - Test 1",                            Description = "RStudio cheatsheet covering dplyr and tidyr.",                            Body = system.file("extdata",                                                "data-wrangling-cheatsheet.pdf",                                               package="salesforcer"),                            FolderId = "00l6A000001EgIwQAK",                            Keywords = "test,cheatsheet,document") result <- sf_create_attachment(document_details, object_name = "Document") result #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 015Kg000000x3bJIAQ TRUE cheatsheet_url <- "https://rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/data-wrangling-cheatsheet.pdf" document_details <- tibble(Name = "Data Wrangling Cheatsheet - Test 2",                            Description = "RStudio cheatsheet covering dplyr and tidyr.",                            Url = cheatsheet_url,                              FolderId = "00l6A000001EgIwQAK",                            Keywords = "test,cheatsheet,document") result <- sf_create_attachment(document_details, object_name = "Document") result #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 015Kg000000x3bOIAQ TRUE

title: Working with Bulk APIs
text: First, load {salesforcer} {dplyr} packages login, needed. really large inserts, updates, deletes, upserts, queries can just add api_type = "Bulk 1.0" functions get benefits using Bulk API instead SOAP REST APIs. change make using REST API Bulk 1.0 API simple adding api_type="Bulk 1.0" function arguments. First, let’s build tbl_df two new records created. differences way REST API returns response information vs.  Bulk 1.0 API. However, changes Salesforce exactly two calls.
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(salesforcer) sf_auth() n <- 4 prefix <- paste0("Bulk-", as.integer(runif(1,1,100000)), "-") new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n),                        My_External_Id__c=paste0(prefix, letters[1:n])) # REST rest_created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts[1:2,],                                    object_name="Contact",                                    api_type="REST") rest_created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   success errors     #>   <lgl>   <list>     #> 1 FALSE   <list [1]> #> 2 FALSE   <list [1]>  # Bulk bulk_created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts[3:4,],                                    object_name="Contact",                                    api_type="Bulk 1.0") bulk_created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   Id    Success Created Error                                                    #>   <lgl> <lgl>   <lgl>   <chr>                                                    #> 1 NA    FALSE   FALSE   DUPLICATE_VALUE:duplicate value found: My_External_Id__… #> 2 NA    FALSE   FALSE   DUPLICATE_VALUE:duplicate value found: My_External_Id__…

title: Working with Bulk APIs
text: show lengthy example using Bulk 1.0 API, workflow creates 2 records, queries , deletes . just example. Typically, ’d want use Bulk APIs REST SOAP APIs dealing 10,000 records.
code: object <- "Contact" created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts, object_name=object, api_type="Bulk 1.0") created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   Id                 Success Created Error #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl> #> 1 003Kg000002AbScIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 2 003Kg000002AbSdIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA  # query bulk my_soql <- sprintf("SELECT Id,                            FirstName,                             LastName                     FROM Contact                      WHERE Id in ('%s')",                     paste0(created_records$Id , collapse="','"))  queried_records <- sf_query(my_soql, object_name=object, api_type="Bulk 1.0") queried_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName LastName         #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 003Kg000002AbScIAK Test      Contact-Create-1 #> 2 003Kg000002AbSdIAK Test      Contact-Create-2  # delete bulk deleted_records <- sf_delete(queried_records$Id, object_name=object, api_type="Bulk 1.0") deleted_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   Id                 Success Created Error #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl> #> 1 003Kg000002AbScIAK TRUE    FALSE   NA    #> 2 003Kg000002AbSdIAK TRUE    FALSE   NA

title: Working with Bulk APIs
text: one limitation Bulk queries support following operations structures SOQL: COUNT ROLLUP SUM GROUP CUBE OFFSET Nested SOQL queries Relationship fields Compound address fields Compound geolocation fields

title: Working with Bulk APIs
text: Salesforce recently introduced Bulk 2.0 API supposed faster consistent JSON/REST based API Bulk 1.0 API. cases noticed ordering result records differ order input data data batched processed asynchronously. Salesforce instead R. However, Bulk 2.0 API returns every single field included call identifying key dataset, problem join key original data bring newly assigned Salesforce Id generated record created Salesforce. However, find just seems wasteful transfer field information back query found significant performance improvement Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0. Finally, note status field names (“Success”, “Created”, “Error”) different Bulk 2.0 API.
code: n <- 20 prefix <- paste0("Bulk-", as.integer(runif(1,1,100000)), "-") new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n),                        test_number__c = 1:n,                        My_External_Id__c=paste0(prefix, letters[1:n]))  created_records_v1 <- sf_create(new_contacts[1:10,],                                  object_name = "Contact",                                  api_type = "Bulk 1.0") created_records_v1 #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>   Id                 Success Created Error #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl> #> 1 003Kg000002AbSmIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 2 003Kg000002AbSnIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 3 003Kg000002AbSoIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 4 003Kg000002AbSpIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 5 003Kg000002AbSqIAK TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> # ℹ 5 more rows  created_records_v2 <- sf_create(new_contacts[11:20,],                                 object_name = "Contact",                                  api_type = "Bulk 2.0") created_records_v2 #> # A tibble: 10 × 7 #>   sf__Id             sf__Created sf__Error FirstName LastName  My_External_Id__c #>   <chr>              <lgl>       <lgl>     <chr>     <chr>     <chr>             #> 1 003Kg000002AbSwIAK TRUE        NA        Test      Contact-… Bulk-60076-k      #> 2 003Kg000002AbSxIAK TRUE        NA        Test      Contact-… Bulk-60076-l      #> 3 003Kg000002AbSyIAK TRUE        NA        Test      Contact-… Bulk-60076-m      #> 4 003Kg000002AbSzIAK TRUE        NA        Test      Contact-… Bulk-60076-n      #> 5 003Kg000002AbT0IAK TRUE        NA        Test      Contact-… Bulk-60076-o      #> # ℹ 5 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: test_number__c <dbl>

title: Working with Bulk APIs
text: simple performance benchmark Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0 APIs small query. general, Bulk 2.0 faster. One potential reason implementation R faster entire recordset parsed downloaded CSV results using Bulk 1.0 API. Bulk 2.0 retrieves data large batches (typically 50,000 records time). encourage users experiment see works best Salesforce Org.
code: soql <- "SELECT Id, Name FROM Contact" bulk1_query <- function(){sf_query(soql, "Contact", api_type="Bulk 1.0")} bulk2_query <- function(){sf_query(soql, api_type="Bulk 2.0")} # Bulk 2.0 doesn't need object name  res <- microbenchmark::microbenchmark(   bulk1_query(),   bulk2_query(),    times=8,    unit = "s" ) res #> Unit: seconds #>           expr      min       lq     mean   median       uq      max neval #>  bulk1_query() 7.633818 7.709295 7.822378 7.815560 7.875023 8.145452     8 #>  bulk2_query() 6.669462 6.681354 6.741376 6.734388 6.783510 6.863041     8  suppressWarnings(suppressMessages(   ggplot2::autoplot(res) +      ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(name="Time [seconds]", n.breaks=6) ))

title: Working with Metadata
text: One common use case Metadata API retrieving information object (fields, permissions, etc.). First, load {salesforcer}, {dplyr}, {purrr} packages login, needed. can use sf_read_metadata() function return list objects metadata. example retrieve metadata Account Contact objects. Note metadata_type argument “CustomObject”. Standard Objects implementation CustomObjects, returned using metadata type. data returned list object definitions highly nested representations. may notice missing really specific details, , picklist values field type “Picklist”. can get information usingsf_describe_object_fields(). example using sf_describe_object_fields() get tbl_df one row field Account object: prefer precise collecting formatting field data can work directly nested lists APIs return. example look picklist values fields Account object. recommended try various metadata functions sf_read_metadata(), sf_list_metadata(), sf_describe_metadata(), sf_describe_objects() order see information best suits use case.
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(purrr) library(salesforcer) sf_auth() read_obj_result <- sf_read_metadata(metadata_type = "CustomObject",                                     object_names = c("Account", "Contact"))  read_obj_result[[1]][c("fullName", "label", "sharingModel", "enableHistory")] #> $fullName #> [1] "Account" #>  #> $label #> [1] "Account" #>  #> $sharingModel #> [1] "ReadWrite" #>  #> $enableHistory #> [1] "false"  first_two_fields_idx <- head(which(names(read_obj_result[[1]]) == "fields"), 2)  # show the first two returned fields of the Account object read_obj_result[[1]][first_two_fields_idx] #> $fields #> $fields$fullName #> [1] "AccountNumber" #>  #> $fields$trackFeedHistory #> [1] "false" #>  #>  #> $fields #> $fields$fullName #> [1] "AccountSource" #>  #> $fields$trackFeedHistory #> [1] "false" #>  #> $fields$type #> [1] "Picklist" acct_fields <- sf_describe_object_fields("Account") acct_fields %>% select(name, label, length, soapType, type) #> # A tibble: 68 × 5 #>   name           label            length soapType    type      #>   <chr>          <chr>            <chr>  <chr>       <chr>     #> 1 Id             Account ID       18     tns:ID      id        #> 2 IsDeleted      Deleted          0      xsd:boolean boolean   #> 3 MasterRecordId Master Record ID 18     tns:ID      reference #> 4 Name           Account Name     255    xsd:string  string    #> 5 Type           Account Type     255    xsd:string  picklist  #> # ℹ 63 more rows  # show the picklist selection options for the Account Type field acct_fields %>%    filter(label == "Account Type") %>%    .$picklistValues #> [[1]] #> # A tibble: 7 × 4 #>   active defaultValue label                      value                      #>   <chr>  <chr>        <chr>                      <chr>                      #> 1 true   false        Prospect                   Prospect                   #> 2 true   false        Customer - Direct          Customer - Direct          #> 3 true   false        Customer - Channel         Customer - Channel         #> 4 true   false        Channel Partner / Reseller Channel Partner / Reseller #> 5 true   false        Installation Partner       Installation Partner       #> # ℹ 2 more rows describe_obj_result <- sf_describe_objects(object_names=c('Account', 'Contact'))  # confirm that the Account object is queryable describe_obj_result[[1]][c('label', 'queryable')] #> $label #> [1] "Account" #>  #> $queryable #> [1] "true"  # now show the different picklist values for the Account Type field all_fields <- describe_obj_result[[1]][names(describe_obj_result[[1]]) == "fields"]  acct_type_field_idx <- which(sapply(all_fields,                                      FUN=function(x){x$label}) == "Account Type") acct_type_field <- all_fields[[acct_type_field_idx]] acct_type_field[which(names(acct_type_field) == "picklistValues")] %>%    map_df(as_tibble) #> # A tibble: 7 × 4 #>   active defaultValue label                      value                      #>   <chr>  <chr>        <chr>                      <chr>                      #> 1 true   false        Prospect                   Prospect                   #> 2 true   false        Customer - Direct          Customer - Direct          #> 3 true   false        Customer - Channel         Customer - Channel         #> 4 true   false        Channel Partner / Reseller Channel Partner / Reseller #> 5 true   false        Installation Partner       Installation Partner       #> # ℹ 2 more rows

title: Working with Metadata
text: Metadata API really shines comes CRUD operations metadata. example create object, add fields , delete object. Note newly created custom fields editable default, meaning able insert records updating field level security user profile. Run following code determine user profiles org updating field permissions object may created example code .
code: # create an object base_obj_name <- "Custom_Account1" custom_object <- list() custom_object$fullName <- paste0(base_obj_name, "__c") custom_object$label <- paste0(gsub("_", " ", base_obj_name)) custom_object$pluralLabel <- paste0(base_obj_name, "s") custom_object$nameField <- list(displayFormat = 'AN-{0000}',                                  label = paste0(base_obj_name, ' Number'),                                  type = 'AutoNumber') custom_object$deploymentStatus <- 'Deployed' custom_object$sharingModel <- 'ReadWrite' custom_object$enableActivities <- 'true' custom_object$description <- paste0(base_obj_name, " created by the Metadata API") custom_object_result <- sf_create_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                            metadata = custom_object)  # add fields to the object custom_fields <- tibble(fullName=c(paste0(base_obj_name, '__c.CustomField3__c'),                                     paste0(base_obj_name, '__c.CustomField4__c')),                          label=c('Test Field3', 'Test Field4'),                          length=c(100, 100),                          type=c('Text', 'Text')) create_fields_result <- sf_create_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomField',                                             metadata = custom_fields)  # delete the object delete_obj_result <- sf_delete_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                          object_names = c('Custom_Account1__c')) # get list of user proviles in order to get the "fullName"  # parameter correct in the next call my_queries <- list(list(type = 'Profile')) profiles_list <- sf_list_metadata(queries = my_queries)  admin_editable <- list(fullName = 'Admin',                         fieldPermissions=list(field=paste0(custom_object$fullName,                                                            '.CustomField3__c'),                                              editable='true'),                         fieldPermissions=list(field=paste0(custom_object$fullName,                                                            '.CustomField4__c'),                                              editable='true'))  # update the field level security to "editable" for your fields prof_update <- sf_update_metadata(metadata_type = 'Profile',                                    metadata = admin_editable)  # now try inserting values into that custom object's fields my_new_data = tibble(CustomField3__c = "Hello World", CustomField4__c = "Hello World") added_record <- sf_create(my_new_data, object_name = custom_object$fullName)

title: Working with Reports

what: Running a Report in your Org
title: Working with Reports
text: Salesforce dedicated page displaying list reports Org. typically follows pattern: https://na1.salesforce.com/00O/o (replace na1 server instance). click report GUI see results. screenshot report may look Org. Note report Id URL bar. report Id ("00O3s000006tE7zEAE") information needed pull results R session, like : Note sf_run_report() function , default, run report asynchronously. means report instance requested function wait retrieve results. advantage using asynchronous report results report stored 24 hours can retrieved saving CPU resources, needed. -depth discussion synchronous vs. asynchronous reports available https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_analytics.meta/api_analytics/sforce_analytics_rest_api_get_reportdata.htm. However, reports relatively small number records synchronous report may faster without round trip creating querying report instance.
code: my_report_id <- "00O3s000006tE7zEAE" results <- sf_run_report(my_report_id) results #> # A tibble: 14 × 8 #>   `Contact ID`    `First Name` `test number` `Contact Owner` `Account ID`    #>   <chr>           <chr>                <dbl> <chr>           <chr>           #> 1 0036A000002C6MW Rose                    NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ4 #> 2 0036A000002C6MX Sean                    NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ4 #> 3 0036A000002C6MY Jack                    99 Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ5 #> 4 0036A000002C6Mb Tim                     NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ8 #> 5 0036A000002C6Mc John                    23 Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ8 #> # ℹ 9 more rows #> # ℹ 3 more variables: `Account Name` <chr>, `Billing City` <chr>, #> #   `Account Owner` <chr>

what: Filtering a Report on the Fly
title: Working with Reports
text: neat thing using API can retrieve results report different filters applied. allows obtain exactly results needed without create separate copies report. takes basic understanding report operators need supplied API, difficult. example includes contact records created prior month belong Account non-NULL Billing City. second example shows return Top N number records combine filter using logical “” instead “”. able determine potential ways filter first reviewing reportFilters element existing report metadata also reviewing list report filter operators. First, can always take report filter specification report metadata tailor needs. example showing get metadata report. can select specific elements better understand structure report. Second, Salesforce API endpoints tell fields report report type, generally, ways can declare filter particular field type . reportTypeMetadata element returned report description also detailed information filter report. example, already contains start end dates applied using “LAST_MONTH” filter value date field. Digging metadata report allow better understand filters can set filtering fly. example notice field names report match names typical API field names object, please review carefully fields report. example, CREATED_DATE report field based CreatedDate object field.
code: # filter records that was created before this month filter1 <- list(column = "CREATED_DATE",                         operator = "lessThan",                          value = "THIS_MONTH")  # filter records where the account billing address city is not empty filter2 <-  list(column = "ACCOUNT.ADDRESS1_CITY",                         operator = "notEqual",                          value = "")  # combine filter1 and filter2 using 'AND' which means that records must meet both filters results_using_AND <- sf_run_report(my_report_id,                                     report_boolean_logic = "1 AND 2",                                    report_filters = list(filter1, filter2)) results_using_AND #> # A tibble: 14 × 8 #>   `Contact ID`    `First Name` `test number` `Contact Owner` `Account ID`    #>   <chr>           <chr>                <dbl> <chr>           <chr>           #> 1 0036A000002C6MW Rose                    NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ4 #> 2 0036A000002C6MX Sean                    NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ4 #> 3 0036A000002C6MY Jack                    99 Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ5 #> 4 0036A000002C6Mb Tim                     NA Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ8 #> 5 0036A000002C6Mc John                    23 Steven Mortimer 0016A0000035mJ8 #> # ℹ 9 more rows #> # ℹ 3 more variables: `Account Name` <chr>, `Billing City` <chr>, #> #   `Account Owner` <chr> # combine filter1 and filter2 using 'OR' which means that records must meet one  # of the filters but also throw in a row limit based on a specific sort order results_using_OR <- sf_run_report(my_report_id,                                    report_boolean_logic = "1 OR 2",                                   report_filters = list(filter1, filter2),                                    sort_by = "Contact.test_number__c",                                    decreasing = TRUE,                                    top_n = 5) results_using_OR #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>   `Contact ID`    `First Name` `test number` `Contact Owner` `Account ID`    #>   <chr>           <chr>                <dbl> <chr>           <chr>           #> 1 0033s00001CWqsU Test                  1000 Steven Mortimer 0013s00001Aizxg #> 2 0033s00001CWqsV Test                  1000 Steven Mortimer 0013s00001Aizxg #> 3 0033s00001CWqt7 Test                  1000 Steven Mortimer 0013s00001Aizxg #> 4 0033s00001CWqt6 Test                  1000 Steven Mortimer 0013s00001Aizxg #> 5 0033s00001CWqsW Test                  1000 Steven Mortimer 0013s00001Aizxg #> # ℹ 3 more variables: `Account Name` <chr>, `Billing City` <chr>, #> #   `Account Owner` <chr> report_details <- sf_describe_report(my_report_id) report_details$reportMetadata$reportType$type #> [1] "ContactList" report_details$reportMetadata$reportFilters #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$column #> [1] "CREATED_DATE" #>  #> [[1]]$filterType #> [1] "fieldValue" #>  #> [[1]]$isRunPageEditable #> [1] TRUE #>  #> [[1]]$operator #> [1] "lessThan" #>  #> [[1]]$value #> [1] "2019-07-19T04:00:00Z" #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]]$column #> [1] "ACCOUNT.ADDRESS1_CITY" #>  #> [[2]]$filterType #> [1] "fieldValue" #>  #> [[2]]$isRunPageEditable #> [1] TRUE #>  #> [[2]]$operator #> [1] "notEqual" #>  #> [[2]]$value #> [1] "" report_details$reportTypeMetadata$standardDateFilterDurationGroups[[6]]$standardDateFilterDurations[[1]] #> $endDate #> [1] "2024-10-31" #>  #> $label #> [1] "Last Month" #>  #> $startDate #> [1] "2024-10-01" #>  #> $value #> [1] "LAST_MONTH" # report fields report_fields <- sf_list_report_fields(my_report_id) head(names(report_fields$equivalentFieldIndices)) #> [1] "CONTACT_CREATED_ALIAS"     "Contact.My_External_Id__c" #> [3] "IS_EMAIL_BOUNCED"          "REPORTS_TO"                #> [5] "ADDRESS2_ZIP"              "LAST_ACTIVITY"  report_filters <- sf_list_report_filter_operators() unique_supported_fields <- report_filters %>%    distinct(supported_field_type) %>%    unlist() unique_supported_fields #>        supported_field_type1        supported_field_type2  #>                       "date"                    "address"  #>        supported_field_type3        supported_field_type4  #>                     "string"                     "double"  #>        supported_field_type5        supported_field_type6  #>                   "picklist"                   "textarea"  #>        supported_field_type7        supported_field_type8  #>            "encryptedstring"                    "percent"  #>        supported_field_type9       supported_field_type10  #>                        "int"                        "url"  #>       supported_field_type11       supported_field_type12  #>                  "reference"                   "datetime"  #>       supported_field_type13       supported_field_type14  #>                    "boolean"                      "phone"  #>       supported_field_type15       supported_field_type16  #> "datacategorygroupreference"                   "currency"  #>       supported_field_type17       supported_field_type18  #>                   "location"                       "html"  #>       supported_field_type19       supported_field_type20  #>                         "id"                       "time"  #>       supported_field_type21       supported_field_type22  #>                      "email"              "multipicklist"  # operators to filter a picklist field picklist_field_operators <- report_filters %>%    filter(supported_field_type == "picklist") picklist_field_operators #> # A tibble: 9 × 3 #>   supported_field_type label         name        #>   <chr>                <chr>         <chr>       #> 1 picklist             equals        equals      #> 2 picklist             not equal to  notEqual    #> 3 picklist             less than     lessThan    #> 4 picklist             greater than  greaterThan #> 5 picklist             less or equal lessOrEqual #> # ℹ 4 more rows

title: Working with Reports
text: API also allows perform many admin functions like creating, copying, updating, deleting reports report instances. Take advantage functions needed keep Org’s report list well-maintained. simple flow creating, updating, deleting single report, amount ’re able customize completely . {salesforcer} package support operation Reports Dashboards REST API supports.
code: # first, grab all possible reports in your Org all_reports <- sf_query("SELECT Id, Name FROM Report")  # second, get the id of the report to update this_report_id <- all_reports$Id[1]  new_report <- sf_copy_report(this_report_id) #> Naming the new report: 'ReportName - Copy'  # third, update the report (2 ways shown) my_updated_report <- sf_update_report(new_report$reportMetadata$id,                                       report_metadata =                                         list(reportMetadata =                                           list(name = "Updated Name!"))) my_updated_report$reportMetadata$name #> [1] "Updated Name!"  # alternatively, pull down its metadata and update the name report_details <- sf_describe_report(new_report$reportMetadata$id) report_details$reportMetadata$name <- paste0(report_details$reportMetadata$name,                                              " - UPDATED AGAIN!")  # update the report by passing the metadata my_updated_report <- sf_update_report(new_report$reportMetadata$id,                                       report_metadata = report_details) my_updated_report$reportMetadata$name #> [1] "Updated Name! - UPDATED AGAIN!"  # fourth, delete that report using its Id success <- sf_delete_report(new_report$reportMetadata$id) success #> [1] TRUE

text: First, load {salesforcer} package log . two ways authenticate: OAuth 2.0 Basic Username-Password NOTE: Beginning February 1, 2022 authentication via username password work Salesforce organizations. date Salesforce begin requiring customers enable multi-factor authentication (MFA). function sf_auth() return error message: always recommended use OAuth 2.0 passwords shared embedded within scripts. information OAuth 2.0 works within {salesforcer} package, please read Getting Started vignette. logging sf_auth(), can check connectivity looking information returned current user. information !

title: An Implementation of Salesforce APIs Using Tidy Principles
text: Salesforce objects objects contain records. One default object “Contact” object. example shows create two records Contact object.
code: n <- 2 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n)) created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts, object_name = "Contact") created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 0033s00001BXHr4AAH TRUE    #> 2 0033s00001BXHr5AAH TRUE

title: An Implementation of Salesforce APIs Using Tidy Principles
text: Salesforce proprietary form SQL called SOQL (Salesforce Object Query Language). SOQL powerful tool allows return attributes records almost object Salesforce including Accounts, Contacts, Tasks, Opportunities, even Attachments! example grab data just created including Account object information Contact record associated . NOTE: example , ’ll notice "Account.Name" column appear results. SOAP REST APIs return empty Account object record relationship account (see #78). reliable way extract rebuild empty columns based query string. Account information, additional column titled "Account.Name" appear results. Note, Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0 APIs return "Account.Name" column NA values query return results differently.
code: my_soql <- sprintf("SELECT Id,                             Account.Name,                             FirstName,                             LastName                      FROM Contact                      WHERE Id in ('%s')",                     paste0(created_records$id , collapse = "','")) queried_records <- sf_query(my_soql) queried_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName LastName         #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 0033s00001BXHr4AAH Test      Contact-Create-1 #> 2 0033s00001BXHr5AAH Test      Contact-Create-2

title: An Implementation of Salesforce APIs Using Tidy Principles
text: creating records can update using sf_update(). Updating record requires pass Salesforce Id record. Salesforce creates unique 18-character identifier record uses know record attach update information provide. Simply include field column update dataset called “Id” information matched. example update records created earlier new first name called “TestTest”.
code: # Update some of those records queried_records <- queried_records %>%   mutate(FirstName = "TestTest")    updated_records <- sf_update(queried_records, object_name = "Contact") updated_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   id                 success #>   <chr>              <lgl>   #> 1 0033s00001BXHr4AAH TRUE    #> 2 0033s00001BXHr5AAH TRUE

title: An Implementation of Salesforce APIs Using Tidy Principles
text: really large operations (inserts, updates, upserts, deletes, queries) Salesforce provides Bulk 1.0 Bulk 2.0 APIs. order use Bulk APIs {salesforcer} can just add api_type = "Bulk 1.0" api_type = "Bulk 2.0" functions operation executed using Bulk APIs. ’s simple. benefits using Bulk API larger datasets operation reduce number individual API calls (organization usually limit total calls) batching requests bulk usually quicker running thousands individuals calls data large. Note: Bulk 2.0 API guarantee order data submitted preserved output. means must join data columns match Ids returned output data submitted. reason, Bulk 2.0 may good solution creating, updating, upserting records need keep track created Ids. Bulk 2.0 API fine deleting records need know Ids successfully deleted.
code: # create contacts using the Bulk API n <- 2 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact-Create-", 1:n)) created_records <- sf_create(new_contacts, "Contact", api_type = "Bulk 1.0") created_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   Id                 Success Created Error #>   <chr>              <lgl>   <lgl>   <lgl> #> 1 0033s00001BXHr9AAH TRUE    TRUE    NA    #> 2 0033s00001BXHrAAAX TRUE    TRUE    NA  # query large recordsets using the Bulk API my_soql <- sprintf("SELECT Id,                            FirstName,                             LastName                     FROM Contact                      WHERE Id in ('%s')",                     paste0(created_records$Id , collapse = "','"))  queried_records <- sf_query(my_soql, "Contact", api_type = "Bulk 1.0") queried_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   Id                 FirstName LastName         #>   <chr>              <chr>     <chr>            #> 1 0033s00001BXHr9AAH Test      Contact-Create-1 #> 2 0033s00001BXHrAAAX Test      Contact-Create-2  # delete these records using the Bulk 2.0 API deleted_records <- sf_delete(queried_records$Id, "Contact", api_type = "Bulk 2.0") deleted_records #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   Id                 sf__Id             sf__Created sf__Error #>   <chr>              <chr>              <lgl>       <lgl>     #> 1 0033s00001BXHr9AAH 0033s00001BXHr9AAH FALSE       NA        #> 2 0033s00001BXHrAAAX 0033s00001BXHrAAAX FALSE       NA

title: An Implementation of Salesforce APIs Using Tidy Principles
text: Salesforce flexible platform provides Metadata API users create, read, update delete entire Salesforce environment objects page layouts . makes easy programmatically setup teardown Salesforce environment. One common use case Metadata API retrieving information object (fields, permissions, etc.). can use sf_read_metadata() function return list objects metadata. example retrieve metadata Account Contact objects. Note metadata_type argument “CustomObject”. Standard Objects implementation CustomObjects, returned using metadata type. data returned list object definitions highly nested representations. may notice missing really specific details, , picklist values field type “Picklist”. can get information using sf_describe_object_fields(). example using sf_describe_object_fields() get tbl_df one row field Account object:
code: read_obj_result <- sf_read_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                     object_names = c('Account', 'Contact'))  read_obj_result[[1]][c('fullName', 'label', 'sharingModel', 'enableHistory')] #> $fullName #> [1] "Account" #>  #> $label #> [1] "Account" #>  #> $sharingModel #> [1] "ReadWrite" #>  #> $enableHistory #> [1] "false"  first_two_fields_idx <- head(which(names(read_obj_result[[1]]) == "fields"), 2)  # show the first two returned fields of the Account object read_obj_result[[1]][first_two_fields_idx] #> $fields #> $fields$fullName #> [1] "AccountNumber" #>  #> $fields$trackFeedHistory #> [1] "false" #>  #>  #> $fields #> $fields$fullName #> [1] "AccountSource" #>  #> $fields$trackFeedHistory #> [1] "false" #>  #> $fields$type #> [1] "Picklist" acct_fields <- sf_describe_object_fields('Account') acct_fields %>% select(name, label, length, soapType, type) #> # A tibble: 68 × 5 #>   name           label            length soapType    type      #>   <chr>          <chr>            <chr>  <chr>       <chr>     #> 1 Id             Account ID       18     tns:ID      id        #> 2 IsDeleted      Deleted          0      xsd:boolean boolean   #> 3 MasterRecordId Master Record ID 18     tns:ID      reference #> 4 Name           Account Name     255    xsd:string  string    #> 5 Type           Account Type     255    xsd:string  picklist  #> # … with 63 more rows  # show the picklist selection options for the Account Type field acct_fields %>%    filter(label == "Account Type") %>%    .$picklistValues #> [[1]] #> # A tibble: 7 × 4 #>   active defaultValue label                      value                      #>   <chr>  <chr>        <chr>                      <chr>                      #> 1 true   false        Prospect                   Prospect                   #> 2 true   false        Customer - Direct          Customer - Direct          #> 3 true   false        Customer - Channel         Customer - Channel         #> 4 true   false        Channel Partner / Reseller Channel Partner / Reseller #> 5 true   false        Installation Partner       Installation Partner       #> # … with 2 more rows

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Parametrized Searches — parameterized_search_control
text: function allowing finer grained control search performed using SOSL

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Parametrized Searches — parameterized_search_control
code: parameterized_search_control(   objects = NULL,   fields_scope = c("ALL", "NAME", "EMAIL", "PHONE", "SIDEBAR"),   fields = NULL,   overall_limit = 2000,   default_limit = 200,   spell_correction = TRUE )

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Parametrized Searches — parameterized_search_control
text: objects character; objects search return response. Multiple objects can provided character vector fields_scope character; scope fields search order limit resources used improve performance fields character; one fields return response sobject specified. fields specified Ids matching records returned. overall_limit numeric; maximum number results return across objects search. default_limit numeric; maximum number results return specified objects. parameter ignored objects argument left NULL. spell_correction logical; specifies whether spell correction enabled user’s search.

text: list parameters passed onto sf_search

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Parametrized Searches — parameterized_search_control

what: Format the detailed data from the
title: Format the detailed data from the
text: function accepts list directly returned API parses return single tbl_df representing detail rows columns report without filters, aggregates, totals.

title: Format the detailed data from the
code: parse_report_detail_rows(   content,   fact_map_key = "T!T",   labels = TRUE,   guess_types = TRUE,   bind_using_character_cols = deprecated() )

title: Format the detailed data from the
text: content list; list returned content function parses JSON response list. fact_map_key character; string providing index section fact map, can access summary detailed data. pattern fact map keys varies report format important know reportFormat property target report . See note details. labels logical; indicator whether returned data label (.e. formatted value) actual value. default, labels returned appear Salesforce dashboard closely align column names. example, "Account.Name" label may "Account B" value 0016A0000035mJEQAY. former (label) accurately reflects "Account.Name". guess_types logical; indicating whether use col_guess() try cast data returned recordset. TRUE col_guess() used along anytime() anydate(). FALSE fields returned character. Specifying FALSE helpful guessing column data type result NA values like return results strings cast script according unique specifications. bind_using_character_cols logical; indicator whether cast data character columns ensure bind_rows fail two paginated recordsets differing datatypes column. Set TRUE rarely, typically set FALSE returns error want columns data character.

title: Format the detailed data from the
text: tbl_df; data frame representing detail rows parsed report result HTTP response rows represent row report columns represent detail columns.

title: Format the detailed data from the
text: fact map key patterns three report types: TABULAR T!T: grand total report. record data values grand total represented key. SUMMARY <First level row grouping_second level row grouping_third   level row grouping>!T: T refers row grand total. MATRIX <First level row grouping_second level row grouping>!<First   level column grouping_second level column grouping>. item row column grouping numbered starting 0. examples fact map keys: 0!T first item first-level grouping. 1!T second item first-level grouping. 0_0!T first item first-level grouping first item second-level grouping. 0_1!T first item first-level grouping second item second-level grouping. function meant used internally. use debugging.
