title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
text: Log using Basic (Username-Password) OAuth 2.0 authentication. OAuth require sharing passwords, require authorizing salesforcer connected app view manage organization. directed web browser, asked sign Salesforce account, grant salesforcer permission operate behalf. default, user credentials cached file named .httr-oauth-salesforcer current working directory.

title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
code: sf_auth(   username = NULL,   password = NULL,   security_token = NULL,   login_url = getOption("salesforcer.login_url"),   token = NULL,   consumer_key = getOption("salesforcer.consumer_key"),   consumer_secret = getOption("salesforcer.consumer_secret"),   callback_url = getOption("salesforcer.callback_url"),   cache = getOption("salesforcer.httr_oauth_cache"),   verbose = FALSE )

title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
text: username Salesforce username, typically email address password Salesforce password security_token Salesforce security token. Note: new security token generated whenever password changed. login_url custom login url; defaults https://login.salesforce.com. needing log sandbox dev environment provide login URL (e.g. https://test.salesforce.com) token optional; actual token object path valid token stored .rds file consumer_key, consumer_secret, callback_url "Consumer Key","Consumer Secret", "Callback URL" using connected app; defaults salesforcer connected apps' consumer key, secret, callback url cache logical character; TRUE means cache using default cache file .httr-oauth-salesforcer, FALSE means cache. string means use specified path cache file. verbose logical; indicator whether print additional detail API call, useful debugging. specifically, set TRUE URL, header, body printed request, along additional diagnostic information available.

title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
text: list invisibly contains 4 elements detailing authentication state

title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
text: link{sf_auth} function invisibly returns following 4 pieces information can reused operations: auth_method character; One two options 'Basic' 'OAuth'. username, password, security token supplied, result 'Basic' authentication. token Token2.0; object returned oauth2.0_token. value NULL auth_method='Basic'. session_id character; unique ID associated user session. session ID obtained X-SFDC-Session header fetched SOAP API's login() call. value NULL auth_method='OAuth'. instance_url character; domain address server Salesforce org subsequent API calls directed . example, https://na21.salesforce.com refers org located 'NA21' server instance located Chicago, USA / Washington DC, USA per Knowledge Article: https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?language=en_US&id=000314281.

title: Log in to Salesforce — sf_auth
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # log in using basic authentication (username-password) sf_auth(username = "test@gmail.com",          password = "test_password",          security_token = "test_token")  # log in using OAuth 2.0 (via browser or cached .httr-oauth-salesforcer) sf_auth()  # log in to a Sandbox environment # Via brower or refresh of .httr-oauth-salesforcer sf_auth(login_url = "https://test.salesforce.com")  # Save token to disk and log in using it saveRDS(salesforcer_state()$token, "token.rds") sf_auth(token = "token.rds") } # }

what: Auxiliary for Controlling Calls to Salesforce APIs — sf_control

text: Typically used internally functions control parameters passed via dots (...), can called directly control behavior API calls. function behaves exactly like glm.control glm function.

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Calls to Salesforce APIs — sf_control
code: sf_control(   AllOrNoneHeader = list(allOrNone = FALSE),   AllowFieldTruncationHeader = list(allowFieldTruncation = FALSE),   AssignmentRuleHeader = list(useDefaultRule = TRUE),   DisableFeedTrackingHeader = list(disableFeedTracking = FALSE),   DuplicateRuleHeader = list(allowSave = FALSE, includeRecordDetails = FALSE,     runAsCurrentUser = TRUE),   EmailHeader = list(triggerAutoResponseEmail = FALSE, triggerOtherEmail = FALSE,     triggerUserEmail = TRUE),   LocaleOptions = list(language = "en_US"),   MruHeader = list(updateMru = FALSE),   OwnerChangeOptions = list(options = list(list(execute = TRUE, type =     "EnforceNewOwnerHasReadAccess"), list(execute = FALSE, type = "KeepAccountTeam"),     list(execute = FALSE, type = "KeepSalesTeam"), list(execute = FALSE, type =     "KeepSalesTeamGrantCurrentOwnerReadWriteAccess"), list(execute = FALSE, type =     "SendEmail"), list(execute = FALSE, type = "TransferAllOwnedCases"), list(execute =     TRUE, type = "TransferContacts"), list(execute = TRUE, type = "TransferContracts"),     list(execute = FALSE, type = "TransferNotesAndAttachments"),       list(execute =     TRUE, type = "TransferOpenActivities"), list(execute = TRUE, type =     "TransferOrders"), list(execute = FALSE, type = "TransferOtherOpenOpportunities"),     list(execute = FALSE, type = "TransferOwnedClosedOpportunities"), list(execute =     FALSE, type = "TransferOwnedOpenCases"), list(execute = FALSE, type =     "TransferOwnedOpenOpportunities"))),   QueryOptions = list(batchSize = 500),   UserTerritoryDeleteHeader = list(transferToUserId = NA),   BatchRetryHeader = list(`Sforce-Disable-Batch-Retry` = FALSE),   LineEndingHeader = list(`Sforce-Line-Ending` = NA),   PKChunkingHeader = list(`Sforce-Enable-PKChunking` = FALSE),   api_type = NULL,   operation = NULL )

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Calls to Salesforce APIs — sf_control
text: AllOrNoneHeader list; containing allOrNone element value TRUE FALSE. control specifies whether call rolls back changes unless records processed successfully. control available SOAP, REST, Metadata APIs following functions: sf_create, sf_delete, sf_update, sf_upsert, sf_create_metadata, sf_delete_metadata, sf_update_metadata, sf_upsert_metadata. information, read Salesforce documentation . AllowFieldTruncationHeader list; containing allowFieldTruncation element value TRUE FALSE. control specifies truncation behavior field types SOAP API version 15.0 later following functions: sf_create, sf_update, sf_upsert. information, read Salesforce documentation . AssignmentRuleHeader list; containing useDefaultRule element value TRUE FALSE assignmentRuleId element. control specifies assignment rule use creating updating Account, Case, Lead following functions: sf_create, sf_update, sf_upsert. information, read Salesforce documentation . DisableFeedTrackingHeader list; containing disableFeedTracking element value TRUE FALSE. control specifies whether changes made current call tracked feeds SOAP API calls made following functions: sf_create, sf_delete, sf_update, sf_upsert. information, read Salesforce documentation . DuplicateRuleHeader list; containing allowSave, includeRecordDetails, runAsCurrentUser elements value TRUE FALSE. control specifies duplicate rules applied using following functions: sf_create, sf_update, sf_upsert. information, read Salesforce documentation . EmailHeader list; containing triggerAutoResponseEmail, triggerOtherEmail, triggerUserEmail elements value TRUE FALSE. control determines email notification sent request processed SOAP API calls made following functions: sf_create, sf_delete, sf_update, sf_upsert, sf_reset_password. information, read Salesforce documentation . LocaleOptions list; containing language element. control specifies language labels returned sf_describe_objects function using SOAP API. value must valid user locale (language country), de_DE en_GB. information, read Salesforce documentation . list valid user locales available . MruHeader list; containing updateMru element value TRUE FALSE. control indicates whether update list recently used items (TRUE) (FALSE) Recent Items section sidebar Salesforce user interface. works SOAP API calls made following functions: sf_create, sf_update, sf_upsert, sf_retrieve, sf_query. information, read Salesforce documentation . OwnerChangeOptions list; containing options element. control specifies details ownership attachments notes record’s owner changed. works SOAP API calls made following functions: sf_update, sf_upsert. information, read Salesforce documentation . QueryOptions list; containing batchSize element. control specifies batch size query results . works SOAP REST API calls made following functions: sf_query, sf_retrieve. information, read Salesforce documentation . UserTerritoryDeleteHeader list; containing transferToUserId element. control specifies user open opportunities assigned current owner removed territory. works sf_delete function using SOAP API. information, read Salesforce documentation . BatchRetryHeader list; containing Sforce-Disable-Batch-Retry element. create bulk job, Batch Retry control lets disable retries unfinished batches included job. works operations run Bulk 1.0 API (e.g. sf_create(., api_type = "Bulk 1.0")) creating Bulk 1.0 job sf_create_job_bulk. information, read Salesforce documentation . LineEndingHeader list; containing Sforce-Line-Ending element. ’re creating bulk upload job, Line Ending control lets specify whether line endings read line feeds (LFs) carriage returns line feeds (CRLFs) fields type Text Area Text Area (Long). works operations run Bulk APIs /creating Bulk job scratch sf_create_job_bulk. However, note readr v1.3.1 CSV files end line feed character ("\n") regardless operating system. usually best specify argument. information, read Salesforce documentation . PKChunkingHeader list; containing Sforce-Enable-PKChunking element. Use PK Chunking control enable automatic primary key (PK) chunking bulk query job. works queries run Bulk 1.0 API either via sf_query(., api_type = "Bulk 1.0")) sf_query_bulk. information, read Salesforce documentation . api_type character; one "REST", "SOAP", "Bulk 1.0", "Bulk 2.0" indicating API use making request. operation character; string defining type operation performed (e.g. "insert", "update", "upsert", "delete", "hardDelete", "query", "queryall").

title: Auxiliary for Controlling Calls to Salesforce APIs — sf_control
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ this_control <- sf_control(DuplicateRuleHeader=list(allowSave=TRUE,                                                     includeRecordDetails=FALSE,                                                     runAsCurrentUser=TRUE)) new_contact <- c(FirstName = "Test", LastName = "Contact-Create") new_record <- sf_create(new_contact, "Contact", control = this_control)  # specifying the controls directly and are picked up by dots new_record <- sf_create(new_contact, "Contact",                         DuplicateRuleHeader = list(allowSave=TRUE,                                                    includeRecordDetails=FALSE,                                                    runAsCurrentUser=TRUE)) } # }

text: converting leads owned queue, owner must specified. accounts contacts owned queue. complete list options control conversion process. Include column input data specify option record. example, want opportunities created converted lead add column input data called doNotCreateOpportunity set value TRUE. default FALSE creates opportunities. order columns input data matter, just names match (case-insensitive). leadId ID Lead convert. Required. convertedStatus Valid LeadStatus value converted lead. Required. accountId Id Account lead merged. Required updating existing account, including person accounts. accountId specified, API creates new account. contactId Id Contact lead merged (contact must associated specified accountId, accountId must specified). Required updating existing contact. contactId specified, API creates new contact implicitly associated Account. ownerId Specifies Id person newly created account, contact, opportunity. client application specify value, owner new object owner lead. opportunityId Id existing opportunity relate lead. opportunityId opportunityName arguments mutually exclusive. Specifying value results error. doNotCreateOpportunity argument TRUE, Opportunity created field must left blank; otherwise, error returned. doNotCreateOpportunity Specifies whether create Opportunity lead conversion (FALSE, default) (TRUE). Set flag TRUE want create opportunity lead. opportunity created default. opportunityName Name opportunity create. name specified, value defaults company name lead. maximum length field 80 characters. opportunityId opportunityName arguments mutually exclusive. Specifying value results error. doNotCreateOpportunity argument TRUE, Opportunity created field must left blank; otherwise, error returned. overwriteLeadSource Specifies whether overwrite LeadSource field target Contact object contents LeadSource field source Lead object (TRUE), (FALSE, default). set field TRUE, client application must specify contactId target contact. sendNotificationEmail Specifies whether send notification email owner specified ownerId (TRUE) (FALSE, default). Salesforce Documentation

title: Create Attachments — sf_create_attachment
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # upload two PDFs from working directory to a particular record as Attachments file_path1 <- here::here("doc1.pdf") file_path2 <- here::here("doc2.pdf") parent_record_id <- "0036A000002C6MmQAK" attachment_details <- tibble(Body = c(file_path1, file_path2),                              ParentId = rep(parent_record_id, 2)) result <- sf_create_attachment(attachment_details)  # the function supports inserting all blob content, just update the # object_name argument to add the PDF as a Document instead of an Attachment document_details <- tibble(Name = "doc1.pdf",                            Description = "Test Document 1",                            Body = file_path1,                            FolderId = "00l6A000001EgIwQAK", # replace with your FolderId!                            Keywords = "example,test,document") result <- sf_create_attachment(document_details, object_name = "Document")  # the Bulk API can be invoked using api_type="Bulk 1.0" which will automatically # take a data.frame of Attachment info and create a ZIP file with CSV manifest # that is required for that API result <- sf_create_attachment(attachment_details, api_type="Bulk 1.0") } # }

title: Create Bulk API Job — sf_create_job_bulk
text: operation character; string defining type operation performed (e.g. "insert", "update", "upsert", "delete", "hardDelete", "query", "queryall"). object_name character; name Salesforce object function operating (e.g. "Account", "Contact", "CustomObject__c"). soql character; string defining SOQL query (e.g. "SELECT Id, Name Account"). external_id_fieldname character; string identifying custom field object set "External ID" field. field used reference objects upserts determine record already exists Salesforce . api_type character; one "REST", "SOAP", "Bulk 1.0", "Bulk 2.0" indicating API use making request. content_type character; one 'CSV', 'ZIP_CSV', 'ZIP_XML', 'ZIP_JSON' indicate type data passed Bulk APIs. Bulk 2.0 API valid value (default) 'CSV'. concurrency_mode character; either "Parallel" "Serial" specifies whether batches completed sequentially parallel. Use "Serial" lock contentions persist "Parallel" mode. Note: argument used Bulk 1.0 API ignored calls using Bulk 2.0 API. column_delimiter character; indicating column delimiter used CSV job data. default value COMMA. Valid values : "BACKQUOTE", "CARET", "COMMA", "PIPE", "SEMICOLON", "TAB", package accepts uses "COMMA". Also, note argument used Bulk 2.0 API ignored calls using Bulk 1.0 API. control list; list parameters controlling behavior API call used. information parameters available look documentation sf_control. ... arguments passed sf_control line_ending character; indicating line ending used CSV job data, marking end data row. default NULL determined operating system using "CRLF" Windows machines "LF" Unix machines. NOTE: readr v1.3.1 CSV files end line feed character ("\n") regardless operating system. usually best specify argument. verbose logical; indicator whether print additional detail API call, useful debugging. specifically, set TRUE URL, header, body printed request, along additional diagnostic information available.

title: Create Object or Field Metadata in Salesforce — sf_create_metadata
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # read the metadata of the existing Account object # we will use this object as a template to create a custom version metadata_info <- sf_read_metadata(metadata_type='CustomObject',                                   object_names=c('Account')) custom_metadata <- metadata_info[[1]] # remove default actionOverrides, this cannot be set during creation custom_metadata[which(names(custom_metadata) %in% c("actionOverrides"))] <- NULL # remove fields since its a custom object and the standard ones no longer exist custom_metadata[which(names(custom_metadata) %in% c("fields"))] <- NULL # remove views so that we get the Standard List Views custom_metadata[which(names(custom_metadata) %in% c("listViews"))] <- NULL # remove links so that we get the Standard Web Links custom_metadata[which(names(custom_metadata) %in% c("webLinks"))] <- NULL # now make some adjustments to customize the object this_label <- 'Custom_Account43' custom_metadata$fullName <- paste0(this_label, '__c') custom_metadata$label <- this_label custom_metadata$pluralLabel <- paste0(this_label, 's') custom_metadata$nameField <- list(displayFormat='AN-{0000}',                                   label='Account Number',                                   type='AutoNumber') custom_metadata$fields <- list(fullName="Phone__c",                                label="Phone",                                type="Phone") # set the deployment status, this must be set before creation custom_metadata$deploymentStatus <- 'Deployed' # make a description to identify this easily in the UI setup tab custom_metadata$description <- 'created by the Metadata API' new_custom_object <- sf_create_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                         metadata = custom_metadata,                                          verbose = TRUE)  # adding custom fields to our object  # input formatted as a list custom_fields <- list(list(fullName='Custom_Account43__c.CustomField66__c',                            label='CustomField66',                            length=100,                            type='Text'),                       list(fullName='Custom_Account43__c.CustomField77__c',                            label='CustomField77',                            length=100,                            type='Text')) # formatted as a data.frame custom_fields <- data.frame(fullName=c('Custom_Account43__c.CustomField88__c',                                        'Custom_Account43__c.CustomField99__c'),                             label=c('Test Field1', 'Test Field2'),                             length=c(44,45),                             type=c('Text', 'Text')) new_custom_fields <- sf_create_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomField',                                          metadata = custom_fields) } # }

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ new_contact <- c(FirstName = "Test", LastName = "Contact") new_records <- sf_create(new_contact, object_name = "Contact") delete <- sf_delete(new_records$id[1],                     AllOrNoneHeader = list(allOrNone = TRUE)) is_deleted <- sf_query(sprintf("SELECT Id, IsDeleted FROM Contact WHERE Id='%s'",                        new_records$id[1]),                        queryall = TRUE) hard_deleted <- sf_empty_recycle_bin(new_records$id[1])  # confirm that the record really is gone (can't be deleted) undelete <- sf_undelete(new_records$id[1]) # if you use queryall you still will find the record for ~24hrs is_deleted <- sf_query(sprintf("SELECT Id, IsDeleted FROM Contact WHERE Id='%s'",                                 new_records$id[1]), queryall = TRUE)                                 # As of v48.0 (Spring 2020) you can query the Ids of all records in the Recycle  # Bin, which makes it easier to clear the entire bin because you can grab the  # Ids of the records first records_in_bin <- sf_query("SELECT Record FROM DeleteEvent") records_emptied_from_bin <- sf_delete(records_in_bin$Record) } # }

text: Run report synchronously expect finish running quickly. Otherwise, recommend run reports API asynchronously reasons: Long running reports lower risk reaching timeout limit run asynchronously. 2-minute overall Salesforce API timeout limit doesn’t apply asynchronous runs. Salesforce Reports Dashboards REST API can handle higher number asynchronous run requests time. title: Execute a report — sf_execute_report
text: Sync Documentation Sync Example Async Documentation Async Example Filtering Results

title: Execute a report — sf_execute_report
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # first, get the Id of a report in your Org all_reports <- sf_query("SELECT Id, Name FROM Report") this_report_id <- all_reports$Id[1]  # then execute a synchronous report that will wait for the results results <- sf_execute_report(this_report_id)  # alternatively, you can execute an async report and then grab its results when done #   - The benefit of an async report is that the results will be stored for up to #     24 hours for faster recall, if needed results <- sf_execute_report(this_report_id, async=TRUE)  # check if completed and proceed if the status is "Success" instance_list <- sf_list_report_instances(report_id) instance_status <- instance_list[[which(instance_list$id == results$id), "status"]] if(instance_status == "Success"){   results <- sf_get_report_instance_results(report_id, results$id) }  # Note: For more complex execution use the report_metadata argument. # This can be done by building the list from scratch based on Salesforce  # documentation (not recommended) or pulling down the existing reportMetadata  # property of the report and modifying the list slightly (recommended).  # In addition, for relatively simple changes, you can leverage the convenience  # function sf_report_wrapper() which makes it easier to retrieve report results report_details <- sf_describe_report(this_report_id) report_metadata <- list(reportMetadata = report_details$reportMetadata) report_metadata$reportMetadata$showGrandTotal <- FALSE report_metadata$reportMetadata$showSubtotals <- FALSE fields <- sf_execute_report(this_report_id,                             report_metadata = report_metadata) } # }

title: Get report instance results — sf_get_report_instance_results
text: fact map key patterns three report types: TABULAR T!T: grand total report. record data values grand total represented key. SUMMARY <First level row grouping_second level row grouping_third   level row grouping>!T: T refers row grand total. MATRIX <First level row grouping_second level row grouping>!<First   level column grouping_second level column grouping>. item row column grouping numbered starting 0. examples fact map keys: 0!T first item first-level grouping. 1!T second item first-level grouping. 0_0!T first item first-level grouping first item second-level grouping. 0_1!T first item first-level grouping second item second-level grouping.

title: Merge Records — sf_merge
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ n <- 3 new_contacts <- tibble(FirstName = rep("Test", n),                        LastName = paste0("Contact", 1:n),                        Description = paste0("Description", 1:n)) new_recs1 <- sf_create(new_contacts, object_name = "Contact")  # merge the second and third into the first record, but set the # description field equal to the description of the second. All other fields # will from the first record or, if blank, from the other records merge_res <- sf_merge(master_id = new_recs1$id[1],                       victim_ids = new_recs1$id[2:3],                       object_name = "Contact",                       master_fields = tibble("Description" = new_contacts$Description[2])) # check the second and third records now have the same Master Record Id as the first merge_check <- sf_query(sprintf("SELECT Id, MasterRecordId, Description                                   FROM Contact WHERE Id IN ('%s')",                                   paste0(new_recs1$id, collapse="','")),                          queryall = TRUE) } # }

Note, argument ignored specifying Top N. can sort records using arrange results returned. top_n integer; integer sets row limit filter report. results ordered appear report unless specified differently via sort_by decreasing arguments. Note, sometimes helpful specify top_n argument report contains many rows, interested subset . Alternatively, can limit count returned rows via report_filters argument. async logical; indicator, default set TRUE, executes report asynchronously. executed asynchronously, function return list attributes created report instance. results can pulled providing report id instance id function sf_get_report_instance_results. Refer details documentation executing report asynchronously preferred. interval_seconds integer; defines seconds attempts check job completion. max_attempts integer; defines max number attempts check job completion stopping. wait_for_results logical; indicating whether wait report finish running data can obtained. Otherwise, return report instance details can used retrieve results async report finished. guess_types logical; indicating whether use col_guess() try cast data returned recordset. TRUE col_guess() used along anytime() anydate(). FALSE fields returned character. Specifying FALSE helpful guessing column data type result NA values like return results strings cast script according unique specifications. bind_using_character_cols logical; indicator whether cast data character columns ensure bind_rows fail two paginated recordsets differing datatypes column. Set TRUE rarely, typically set FALSE returns error want columns data character. fact_map_key character; string providing index section fact map, can access summary detailed data. pattern fact map keys varies report format important know reportFormat property target report . See note details. verbose logical; indicator whether print additional detail API call, useful debugging. specifically, set TRUE URL, header, body printed request, along additional diagnostic information available.

title: Get a report's data in tabular format — sf_run_report
text: fact map key patterns three report types: TABULAR T!T: grand total report. record data values grand total represented key. SUMMARY <First level row grouping_second level row grouping_third   level row grouping>!T: T refers row grand total. MATRIX <First level row grouping_second level row grouping>!<First   level column grouping_second level column grouping>. item row column grouping numbered starting 0. examples fact map keys: 0!T first item first-level grouping. 1!T second item first-level grouping. 0_0!T first item first-level grouping first item second-level grouping. 0_1!T first item first-level grouping second item second-level grouping.

title: Get a report's data in tabular format — sf_run_report
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # find a report in your org and run it all_reports <- sf_query("SELECT Id, Name FROM Report") this_report_id <- all_reports$Id[1] results <- sf_run_report(this_report_id)  # apply your own filters to that same report # set up some filters, if needed # filter records that was created before this month filter1 <- list(column = "CREATED_DATE",                 operator = "lessThan",                  value = "THIS_MONTH")  # filter records where the account billing address city is not empty filter2 <-  list(column = "ACCOUNT.ADDRESS1_CITY",                  operator = "notEqual",                   value = "")  # combine filter1 and filter2 using 'AND' so that records must meet both filters results_using_AND <- sf_run_report(my_report_id,                                     report_boolean_logic = "1 AND 2",                                    report_filters = list(filter1, filter2))  # combine filter1 and filter2 using 'OR' which means that records must meet one  # of the filters but also throw in a row limit based on a specific sort order results_using_OR <- sf_run_report(my_report_id,                                    report_boolean_logic = "1 OR 2",                                   report_filters = list(filter1, filter2),                                    sort_by = "Contact.test_number__c",                                    decreasing = TRUE,                                    top_n = 5) } # }

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # create an object that we can update base_obj_name <- "Custom_Account1" custom_object <- list() custom_object$fullName <- paste0(base_obj_name, "__c") custom_object$label <- paste0(gsub("_", " ", base_obj_name)) custom_object$pluralLabel <- paste0(base_obj_name, "s") custom_object$nameField <- list(displayFormat = 'AN-{0000}',                                  label = paste0(base_obj_name, ' Number'),                                  type = 'AutoNumber') custom_object$deploymentStatus <- 'Deployed' custom_object$sharingModel <- 'ReadWrite' custom_object$enableActivities <- 'true' custom_object$description <- paste0(base_obj_name, " created by the Metadata API") custom_object_result <- sf_create_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                            metadata = custom_object) # now update the object that was created update_metadata <- custom_object  update_metadata$fullName <- 'Custom_Account1__c' update_metadata$label <- 'New Label Custom_Account1' update_metadata$pluralLabel <- 'Custom_Account1s_new' updated_custom_object_result <- sf_update_metadata(metadata_type = 'CustomObject',                                                    metadata = update_metadata) } # }

title: salesforcer 1.0.0 release
text: Increase package’s default Salesforce API version 52.0 (Summer ’21). Remove uses {RForcecom} archived CRAN 6/8/2021 (#101) Remove LazyData option DESCRIPTION since data() utilized Deprecate argument sf_write_csv() path file done {readr} v1.4.0. Deprecate argument bind_using_character_cols always need bind character parse guess_types=TRUE. Per comments tidyverse/readr#588 tidyverse/readr#98, must read data character first use type_convert() ensure use values column guess type. default read_csv() use first 1,000 rows guess_max argument set Inf. Change lifecycle status “Maturing” “Status” per retirement “Maturing” {lifecycle} package. documentation notes: Previously used maturing functions lay somewhere experimental stable. stopped using stage , like questioning, ’s clear actionable information stage delivers. addition, lifecycle guidance states experimental packages version numbers less 1.0.0 may major changes future. {salesforcer} package achieved stable state core functionality implemented focus backwards compatibility due volume users.

title: salesforcer 0.2.0 release

title: salesforcer 0.2.0 release
text: CAUTION: release automated test coverage R 4.0.0 greater. Users still able install run using R (>= 3.6.0). However, recommended upgrade R 4.0.0 greater.

title: salesforcer 0.2.0 release
text: Add experimental support Reports Dashboards REST API. Add support Bulk 2.0 queries added Salesforce version 47.0 (Winter ’20). CAUTION: Bulk 2.0 API now default API using sf_query_bulk() sf_run_bulk_query(). Please test prior upgrading production environment running bulk queries. Standardize column order format query CRUD operations prioritizes object type Ids fields finaly relationship fields. CAUTION: switch order columns returned existing code. Please test prior upgrading production environment column ordering breaking change. example prioritize following fields queries alphabetically within prioritization waterfall: sObject field first (indicates record’s object multiple objects returned results) Id field second (Id, id, sf__Id) Salesforce record success status (Success, success, sf_Success) Salesforce record created status (Created, created, sf__Created) Salesforce record error(s) status (Error, error, errors, errors.statusCode, errors.fields, errors.message, sf__Error) fields target object (e.g. Name, Phone, etc.) Relationship fields (fields parent child target). example, anything typically containing dot like Account.Id, Owner.Name, etc. Standardize names functions submit long running jobs Salesforce. functions now start sf_run_*. However, original names aliased new names version acknowledge old function names without deprecation warning.example, new names : sf_query_bulk() ==> sf_run_bulk_query() sf_bulk_operation() ==> sf_run_bulk_operation() sf_run_report() Add support logging proxy without use OAuth 2.0 authentication method. proxy support first implemented {salesforcer} 0.1.4, supported proxy connections logging via OAuth 2.0. Now, untested version proxy support basic authentication implemented. means proxy users able login using just username, password, security token organization implemented OAuth 2.0 want use OAuth 2.0 logging via package. Add lifecycle badges signal maturity different package aspects. Add two vignettes, one outlines query types supported package another outlines new report functionality introduced release. Add enhanced query test coverage test script. Remove dependency {data.table} build R-devel. affect sf_read_metadata().

title: salesforcer 0.2.0 release
text: Fix bug prevented enabling PKChunking Bulk 1.0 queries. Users can now specify using TRUE/FALSE details like chunkSize imply TRUE. results parsed appropriately waiting individual batches finish. (#46) Fix bugs REST SOAP API queries prevent infinite looping mangling results relationship queries, specifically parent--child nested queries. (#19, #35, #38, #54) Fix bug REST SOAP APIs creation record fails duplicate rules return duplicate match results well cause entire function call fail parse results. Now status code message returned function execute successfully even record created due rule.

title: salesforcer 0.1.4 release

title: salesforcer 0.1.4 release
text: Rebuilt package R 4.0 (issues observed 3.6.3, 4.0.0, 4.0.1) (#53) Upgrade Salesforce version 48.0 (Spring ’20) version 46.0 (Summer ’19) Add support connections proxy setting package options (#32) CRUD operations now automatically cast date datetime (Date, POSIXct, POSIXlt, POSIXt) formats accepted string format recognized Salesforce (YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sssZ). Add batch_size argument support specifying custom batch sizes Bulk jobs Add sf_convert_lead() takes leads associate corresponding Accounts, Contacts, Opportunities directed input along many options send email new owner, block opportunity creation, . Add sf_create_attachment() along vignette better describes interact attachments blob data. Add Attachment Metadata vignettes along updated Bulk vignette.

title: salesforcer 0.1.4 release
text: Fix issue REST query correctly passing honoring batch size control argument paginate results Fix issue results REST query pagination function looping infinitely bug implementation continue using next_records_url previously passed function (#54) Fix issue results Bulk 1.0 query batches returning fewer rows expected using content(..., ="text") truncated results instead using content(..., type="text/csv") (#54) Fix issue details object’s picklist contains NULLs (e.g. validFor entry picklist value NULL) now replaced NA can bound together data.frame (#27) Fix issue NA values create, update, upsert operations setting fields blank Bulk APIs, SOAP REST APIs. Now NA values record set field blank across APIs (#29) Fix issue supplying NA values Id field certain operations result cryptic error message ("BAD_REQUEST: Unsupported   Tooling Sobject Type"); affected operations : delete, undelete, emptyRecycleBin, retrieve, update, findDuplicatesByIds

title: salesforcer 0.1.3 release
text: CRAN release: 2019-06-10

title: salesforcer 0.1.3 release
text: Upgrade version 46.0 (Summer ’19) version 45.0 (Spring ’19) Add RForcecom backward compatible version rforcecom.getObjectDescription() Add sf_describe_object_fields() tidier version rforcecom.getObjectDescription() Allow users control whether query results kept character types guessed (#12) Add sf_get_all_jobs_bulk() users can see retrieve details bulk jobs (#13) Add new utility functions sf_set_password() sf_reset_password() (#11) Add two new functions check duplicates (sf_find_duplicates(), sf_find_duplicates_by_id()) (#4) Add new function download attachments disk (sf_download_attachment()) (#20) Add functionality infer object_name argument, required bulk queries, left blank. Add control argument package functions dots (...) allows dozen different control parameters listed sf_control() fed existing function calls tweak default behavior. example, like override duplicate rules can adjust DuplicateRuleHeader. like certain assignment rule run newly created records, pass AssignmentRuleHeader (#4, #5) Add new function sf_undelete() take records Recycle Bin Add new function sf_empty_recycle_bin() remove records permanently Recycle Bin Add new function sf_merge() combines 3 records type 1 record (#22)

title: salesforcer 0.1.3 release
text: Fix bug Username/Password authenticated sessions working api_type = “Bulk 1.0” Fix bug Bulk 1.0 queries timeout hit error trying abort since supported aborting Bulk 2.0 jobs (#13) Fix bug production environment logins possible hard coding (@weckstm, #18) Enhance sf_describe_object_fields() robust nested list elements also return picklist labels values tibble (#16) Fix bug four bulk operation options (content_type, concurrency_mode, line_ending, column_delimiter) passed top level generic functions like sf_create(), sf_update(), etc. However, line_ending now moved sf_control function longer explicitly listed bulk operations argument. (@mitch-niche, #23) Ensure SOAP, REST, Bulk 2.0 APIs verbose argument prints XML JSON along URL call can replicated via cURL programming language (#8)

title: salesforcer 0.1.2 release
text: Add support Bulk 1.0 operations “create”, “update”, “upsert”, “delete” “hardDelete” Bulk 2.0 operations, default, now return single tbl_df containing successful records, error records, unprocessed records Create internal functions explicitly call API operation. example, sf_create() routes sf_create_soap(), sf_create_rest(), sf_bulk_operation().

title: salesforcer 0.1.1 release
text: Add sf_search() REST SOAP API support SOSL free text search Add sf_describe_objects() REST SOAP API return object metadata Add REST API support upsert (sf_upsert()) Add SOAP API support following operations: sf_create() sf_update() sf_delete() sf_retrieve() Add Metadata API support following operations: sf_create_metadata() sf_read_metadata() sf_update_metadata() sf_upsert_metadata() sf_delete_metadata() sf_describe_metadata() sf_list_metadata() sf_rename_metadata() sf_retrieve_metdata() sf_deploy_metdata() Update default file name cached token .httr-oauth-salesforcer clash package token names.

title: salesforcer 0.1.1 release
text: sf_user_info() returning argument length zero token automatically refreshed calling GET. sf_token() ignoring basic authorized sessions since looking token using token_avaiable(). Replace sf_auth_check() now considers session token “available” (#1).

title: salesforcer 0.1.0 release
text: OAuth 2.0 Basic authentication methods (sf_auth()) Query operations via REST Bulk APIs (sf_query()) CRUD operations (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) REST Bulk APIs: sf_create() sf_retrieve() sf_update() sf_upsert() sf_delete() Backwards compatible versions RForcecom package functions: rforcecom.login() rforcecom.getServerTimestamp() rforcecom.query() rforcecom.bulkQuery() rforcecom.create() rforcecom.update() rforcecom.upsert() rforcecom.delete() Basic utility calls: sf_user_info() sf_server_timestamp() sf_list_rest_api_versions() sf_list_resources() sf_list_api_limits() sf_list_objects()
